text: <@U027QSHHCMN> has joined the channel

I was just looking at a really small volume market and the market_book that I pull for it is clearly not showing the same thing as the website. The website has a batb at 1.01 and 1.89, batl at 2.1, 110, and 1000 (but shows 0 volume for the latter two). The market book only shows batb: 1.01, batl: 1000. I've been looking at it for a solid 10-20 minutes and restarted the stream several times, nothing has changed on either the website or the market book. Does that check out with anyone else's experience? It seems like I can buy from the website's interface, so it is extra disconcerting not to see the same book from the API. What gives?

elements.text: I was just looking at a really small volume market and the market_book that I pull for it is clearly not showing the same thing as the website. The website has a batb at 1.01 and 1.89, batl at 2.1, 110, and 1000 (but shows 0 volume for the latter two). The market book only shows batb: 1.01, batl: 1000. I've been looking at it for a solid 10-20 minutes and restarted the stream several times, nothing has changed on either the website or the market book. Does that check out with anyone else's experience? It seems like I can buy from the website's interface, so it is extra disconcerting not to see the same book from the API. What gives?

text: Also, the volume on the 1.89 and 2.1 offers/bids is over a hundred GBP each.

text: Hi MacrcoPolo, I just looked more, and I found that the the raw data part of the market book object has the correct info, but the fancier betfairlightweight one (the market_book.runners. etc one) which is where I was getting my data from, only has the 1.01 and 1000 odds that I described before. I've got a few pictures, hopefully I'm not spamming the group too much:

text:
I think i found the reason for this and it is a design decision:
> """"
> django style `lazy` object creation, the main bulk of processing
> is turning {priceSize} into <PriceSize> objects but this is
> pointless a lot of the time as the object is not used or can be
> handled as a dict instead.
> The inclusion of slots further reduces the processing time as well
> as reducing memory.
> This optimisation will improve normal streaming as well as
> backtesting, with more speed, less CPU + ram and minimal reduction
> in usability.
> """

elements.text: I think i found the reason for this and it is a design decision:

""""
django style `lazy` object creation, the main bulk of processing
is turning {priceSize} into <PriceSize> objects but this is
pointless a lot of the time as the object is not used or can be
handled as a dict instead.
The inclusion of slots further reduces the processing time as well
as reducing memory.
This optimisation will improve normal streaming as well as
backtesting, with more speed, less CPU + ram and minimal reduction
in usability.
"""

text: What is your market data filter? Are you actually asking for the displayed prices?

text: As <@UBS7QANF3> has said, are you requesting virtual prices to get the same display as the website? By default, bflw and Flumine display the actual prices rather than Betfair's virtual ones. The response will have 'atb' for actual prices and 'batb' if they're virtual.

elements.text: As

has said, are you requesting virtual prices to get the same display as the website? By default, bflw and Flumine display the actual prices rather than Betfair's virtual ones. The response will have 'atb' for actual prices and 'batb' if they're virtual.

text: Not quite correct <@U016TGY3676>, it's bdatb for virtual. batb is non-virtual with a limit on the number of levels

elements.text: Not quite correct
, it's bdatb for virtual. batb is non-virtual with a limit on the number of levels
